body.p: Most companies do not start new DITA-based projects from zero, they already have content written in various other formats and somehow they need that content converted to DITA. In this blog post I will try to give some conversion advice depending on the format in which your current project has.

section.title: Migrating DocBook content to DITA.
section.p:
Because DocBook content is XML migrating it to DITA is quite straight forward:
You first convert the DocBook document to a single large DITA composite file and you can do that with the predefined transformation scenario bundled with Oxygen called DocBook to DITA.
There is an utility XSLT stylesheet on the Oxygen XML GitHub account which can convert a DITA composite to a DITA Map with separate DITA topic files:

section.title: Migrating Microsoft Word content to DITA
section.p: The Oxygen XML User's manual has a detailed topic enumerating the possibilities to convert Microsoft Word content to DITA:

section.title: Migrating Excel content to DITA
section.p: You can use Oxygen's smart paste functionality to copy content from an Excel spreadsheet and paste it inside an opened DITA topic. Also as an alternate possibility the Oxygen resources converter-addon was updated to be able to batch convert Excel to DITA:

section.title: Migrating LibreOffice content to DITA
section.p: LibreOffice documents can be saved in Word format so once you do that you can apply the Word to DITA conversion choices above. Or you can save the LibreOffice documents to DocBook and then apply DocBook to DITA conversions.

section.title: Migrating Markdown content to DITA
section.p: The DITA Open Toolkit publishing engine bundled with Oxygen allows you to refer to Markdown files directly in a DITA Map and either publish directly or export the Markdown files to DITA one by one: . Or if you want batch conversions you can use the Oxygen Resources Converter add-on:

section.title: Migrating HTML content to DITA
section.p: Using Oxygen's smart paste functionality you can open the HTML documents in a web browser, then copy the contents and paste in a DITA topic opened in Oxygen in the Author visual editing mode. Or if you want batch conversions you can use the Oxygen Resources Converter add-on:

section.title: Migrating unstructured FrameMaker to DITA
section.p: There is a FrameMaker plugin which can be used for this conversion:

section.title: Migrating MadCap content to DITA
section.p: Some recent MadCap versions seem to have facilities to export content directly to DITA. Otherwise you will need to convert XHTML content to DITA with a custom XSLT stylesheet to preserve variable references.

section.title: Migrating other formats to DITA
section.p: You may find third party applications like Pandoc which can convert your content to HTML or to some kind of XML format like DocBook. Once you have HTML or DocBook content you can convert them to DITA using the advice above.
